@2:10 Positive Predictive Value (PPV) := P(Cancer | +) => based on simple counting (no need to use Bayes rule)

PPV = TP/(TP + FP) = TPR.r/ (TPR.r + FPR.(1-r))

Where:
TP := True Positive cases
FP := False Positive cases
TPR := True Positive Rate := Sensitivity
FPR := False Positive Rate := 1 - Specificity := 1 - TNR
r := Prior prevalence rate

But what happens if your FPR approaches zero, e. g. a Covid PCR-Test? Here the Bayes Factor would limit towards infinity, making any arbitrarily small prior odd above 1:0, which of course is nonsense. So is there any border of meaning for this formula concerning decreasing FPRs?

The "Bayes factor" is a form of odds. In the examples of the video (you can go to 15:50 for reference), the factor of true positives divided by false positives is 90% / 9% = 10. Well, you could also say that THE ODDS of TP : FP is 90 : 9; if you simplify it, 10 : 1. It means that to any given positive result, the odds of being a true positive (TP) is 10 : 1, or inversely, the odds of being a false positve (FP), are 1 : 10. For the false negatives (FN) is 1 : 9, and the true positives (TP), 9 : 1.

Seeing the factor as odds might seem like a random, silly thing, done just for the sake of it. But it actually makes the final formula (at 16:18) even more elegant and intuitive:

O ( D | + ) = O ( D ) x O ( TP )

That reads like "the odds of having the disease, given that the test is positive, is equal to the prior odds of having the disease (or you can see it as "the general odds of having the disease, with no prior knowledge about the person") times the odds of the result being a true positive."

And that should make total sense! "the general odds of having the disease by the odds of a test being a true positive" is THE DEFINITION of O (D | +): Odds of Disesase given Positive Result. The following also make total sense:

O ( D | - ) = O ( D ) x O ( FN )

O ( ¬D | - ) = O ( ¬D ) x O ( TN )

O ( ¬D | + ) O ( ¬D ) x O ( FP )

Notice that anytime the left-hand side (D or ¬D) inside the parentheses is according to the right-hand side ( + or - ), like ( D | + ), I used a T (TP or TN) and when they were opposites, like ( ¬D | + ), I used an F (FP or FN). Take some time to understand why that is.

*An additional note to anyone who knows basic programming: odds (or Bayes factors) are like getting a random number and comparing it to an if statement. Multiplying odds, is like NESTING if statements, meaning you get a second number, and so on, and make another conditional with it, one for each odds, or Bayes factor. Isn't that awesome to visualize? For me it makes the whole thing really obvious.

For those interested, here follows my simple algebraic derivation of the formula O(H|E) = O(H) X { p(E|H) / p(E|~H) } (ie, posterior odds = prior odds X Likelihood Ratio)

p(H | E) . p(E) = p(E|H) . p(H) (1)
p(~H|E) . p(E) = p(E|~H) . p(~H) (2)

(1) / (2) ==> { p(H | E) / p(~H|E) } = { p(H) / p(~H) } X { p(E|H) / p(E|~H) }

or {posterior odds} = {prior odds} X {Likelihood Ratio}

The important thing about conditional probability is the vertical line that means "given that".  The probability of having a heart attack  from playing tennis at age 60 might be estimated as 1 in 1000.  That may be true for the "population in general" but not if a player aged 60 has had a heart attack previously.  In that case the probability would be required to be "what is the probability of having a heart attack - given that - the person had one already".  This might be 1 in 10 and not 1 in 1000.

A summary just for myself:

Problem - Commonly accepted measures of test "goodness", sensitivity and specificity, are not handy when trying to calculate/estimate an actual a posteriori probability of a disease.

Solution - Represent the question in terms of updating the odds, i.e., how does new data (a medical test) affects your prior odds of being positive (sick). Thus, a measure of the test's impact would be its Bayesian Factor.

Math - Probabilites = "m out of n", Odds = "m to n". Bayesian rule can be represented using odds instead of probabilities, and in many cases it brings better illustrative power.

Me waiting for "ESSENTIALS OF PROBABILITY":

=..(

Prevalence = P(1)
Sensitivity = P(+|1) = P(+,1) / P(1)
Specificity = P(-|0) = P(-,0) / P(0)

Bayes Factor = P(+|1) / P(+|0) = Sensitivity / (1 - Specificity)

Positive Predictive Value = P(1|+)
= P(1,+) / P(+)
≈ P(1) * Bayes Factor if P(1) << 1%

Think of it like this.

When you stack millions of 2d spaces on top of one another, you get a 3d space.

And when you travel through these 2d spaces or along the z coordinate (from x,y,z) then it dissappear for each 2d dimension.
So imagine thisin the 2nd dimension, you have a man then a wall beside him and empty space on the other side of the wall.

This man has a ball, and he wants to put it behind the wall, but he can not because it goes up infinitely up the y coordinate, and the ball can not go through the ground.

So in order for him to put the 2d ball around the 2d wall he has to take the ball through the 2d dimension beside him, that does not have a wall. So he does that and it is now there, walking past the area of the wall.

Now when he goes back to his dimension he is on the other side of the infinitely tall wall, and he did not go through it, he went around it.

So this is what someone in the 4th dimension would think for an example of this for us, we have a wall covering the x, and y coordinate. So we travel to the dimension of ours that is beside us, and take a few steps. Then we go back to our dimension and we are behind the wall.

But the thing that is hard to imagine, is what the person in the 4th dimension looks like, because they live in multiple of our dimension stacked on top and beside eachother. Just as we live inside of a bunch of 2d dimensions stacked on top of eachother.
---------------------
Now what about the 1st and 0th dimensions.

Well for the first dimension it is just a noodle like line, all they have in there view is a dot. They travel around that dot by going into the noodle beside them, going forward, and going back to theirs.

As for the 0th dimension, it is just a 0 cube. It is just a block that is infinitely small compared to the 1st dimension noodle.
It has nothing to go around, for it is nothing. Yet it is... it is infinitely small... but it still is. It still exists.

Math in general has presented very little difficulty to me in school, college and work, but statistics and probability have always been a complete mess as I've never found any coherent frame of reference by with to understand them. A lot of the issues, I think, are because they're presented using terms that are in daily use with often very different definitions to their mathematical definitions, leading to high levels of miscommunication between presenter and listener without either party realising that communication has failed. Almost all videos of this type end by concluding that the results are now obvious, denying or ignoring that every intuition normal humans have on the significance of the information presented remains wrong. If putting a nice animation together was a real fix for the intuition black hole this whole area of math is, then people wouldn't still be making more and more videos, claiming to simplify it or explain it.

Specific to medical testing, there's the further confounding factor in that the companies that are trying to sell you their product, or persuade your doctor to bill you for their product, put a lot of money and time into presenting their results in the way that makes them look as good as possible and use every trick they can to direct people towards drawing intuitive but incorrect results as described in the video.

As a further example of how utterly inscrutable statistics is as a subject to anyone interested in learning more themselves, just google the definition of 'Null Hypothesis'. There appear to be just enough conflicting definitions to make the term meaningless unless it is specifically defined in the particular use context first and this is a statistics term that's not in common use, so there's no good excuse for it.

This has nothing to do with being any sort of “paradox”, but it’s instead a failure of the general population to understand basic statistics.  While there are different methodologies to be used in inference vs prediction problems, the point at which those methodologies need to change is when they are no longer robust, not when  general people are confused as to what they mean.  It is the job of statisticians to accurately present and interpret the results of bayes rule so that their audiences will understand.  If they don’t do that, or if they are dissatisfied with the results of the method/test, then that’s on them or the test, not on bayes rule itself

The problem from a doctor's point of view is the purely mathematical approach to estimating the outcome of an event. By nature, physicians like to think that no matter what the odds are, they may have an influence on the result, and usually a positive one (self-confidence, intention to help the patient, etc), or that they can tweak the test their way to lower the risk of failure by knowing the underlying mechanism. Seeing their own work being reduced to statistics is highly counterintuitive, it's the others making the errors, not oneself. Also, you're trained by med school and experience to trust yourself when you have a hard choice to make, which is certainly good in critical situations, but not necessarily in analytical ones.

at one point you mentioned that there is no objective best way to frame Bayes Rule, but I disagree. unless you have an academic interest in statistics, 99% of the public will never understand Bayes Rule by looking at how the formulas are arranged, or if they do at first they will not remember how to apply it. the idea has to be broken down into simple high impact words like True Positive, False Negative, True Negative and False Positive. or how you proposed that tests should be seen as "updating" a previous guess rather than simply "giving" the final answer--excellent!

we really ought to talk about this instead of Sensitivity and Specificity which honestly are terrible words and should be replaced with True Positive Rate and True Negative Rate. or we can just go one step further and adopt the most important point you made and that is talking about Bayes Factor instead. 19:26-19:46 the entire thesis summarized. absolutely perfect. it completely eliminates the need to consider sample sizes in order to understand Bayes Rule (901 vs 90 women etc, honestly it helps to visualize the explanation but in practice is cumbersome and impossible to remember)--this is crucial because the public and the press is terrible with large numbers but is already familiar with how to comprehend rates and odds in describing problems and in decision making (even if it is to make poor decisions like gambling). the layman will easily understand that even a test with poor Bayes Factor can become a good test if done twice in a row or thrice in a row, because assuming you keep getting a positive result, the final guess keeps getting updated by compounding higher and higher. but at the end of the day the tests only updates the odds for what you started with--the prior--so even an accurate test can be unreliable if coupled with an inaccurate prior.

the gynaeycologist example: experts are typically bad at logical quizzes because they can't help but bring their experience into the calculation when that is precisely forbidden. i think what happened is that they were given the 1% prior probability but they threw it out the window and substituted their own Bayesian priors--they are experts after all--and so failed the logic test. but it's not as bad as it looks because in a real world scenario they should be applying their experience--as a result their Bayesian priors are way more reliable than that of non gynaes. typically by the time a person with a positive test is referred to a gynae--it's no longer 1%.

The following is only indirectly related to the video, it may only be interesting to those interested in Bayesian inference and medical decision making. I think your instruction on prevalence, and predictive value would also be a good instruction for medical AI researchers. Reports on successful applications of AI in medicine are often accompanied by claims of outperforming expert physicians. There are some pitfalls to that conclusion, one of which is the failure to consider prevalence of disease in the population of patients versus prevalence of disease in the dataset used to develop and test the deep neural network. The decisions made by expert physicians is shaped by the prevalence of disease in the population (that the expert physician serves), and the risk (in terms of patient suffering) of a false negative result versus benefit (in terms of avoiding patient death or suffering). The experts prior will be based on a population separate from the dataset (it is also an intuitive or fuzzy prior, rather than a measured value). If the test cases used to compare the experts decision to a deep neural network decision are derived form a random sample of the dataset (splitting the dataset into training, validation, and test cases), then the deep neural network will have a better prior (a measured prior likely to be close to the random sampled test subset). The deep neural network has a head start on the expert physician. It is also hard to eliminate the bias of an expert physician to place more importance on false negative errors rather than false positive errors. The consequence of a false negative error are more negative for patient outcomes (patient may die of breast cancer, or require harsher treatment to survive) than a false positive error (anxiety, discomfort of a biopsy). The expert has learned to error on the safe side for the patient's sake. Deep neural networks can incorporate the negative effects of false negative versus false positives in the threshold for classification, but I haven't seen much use of that adjustment. Usually, the deep neural network will mathematically optimize the threshold for the greatest "accuracy". The deep neural network is being compared to the expert physician with a process for which the deep neural network was programmed for, whereas the physician is programmed by experience with patient outcomes. There are some research results where the AI has been applied to true patient populations rather than rely on public datasets in which there may be some selection of cases submitted to the dataset. I assume those successful applications will progress to further clinical trials for application of the algorithm in clinical practice.

At first I was really confused that accurate tests don't give good predictions. Then I realised that what it actually says is that the rarer the thing you're trying to detect is, the more accurate your test has to be in order to detect it.

If you look at the first example, you'll see that the sensitivity and specificity (both around 90%, or 9 in 10) is an order of magnitude worse than the prevalence (1%, or 1 / 100). Trying to use that test to predict the illness is like bringing a knife to a gunfight. But if you raise sensitivity and specificity to 99%, you'll find that you have 50% chance of detecting.

In general, if x% percent of the population has the illness, then we can prove that if the specificity and sensitivity is 1-x%, we'll have a 50% chance of detecting the illness. The reason is that if you have a prevalence of x%, then your odds are x:(1-x). So if your sensitivity and specificity is 1-x, then your Bayes' factor is x/(1-x), and multiplying the odds by the Bayes' factor gives (1-x):(1-x) = 1:1, i.e 50%.

You give a very round-about explanation for some metrics which are used commonly in machine learning when classifying things:

namely, recall and precision:

The recall tells you how likely your test (in machine learning this would be your "model") is to correctly identify positive cases.
This is the same as sensitivity.
HOWEVER: The precision tells you how likely you are to actually have the disease, given that you tested positive.


recall = TP/(TP+FP)
precision = TP/(TP+FN)
accuracy = (TP+TN)/Total

Where TP is the number of true positives, FN is the number of false negatives etc.

in the example from the beginning, the precision is 9/(9+89) = 9/99=1/11

You don't even need bayes here, and IMHO the frequentist approach is way simpler, as you can directly calculate on probabilities.

btw, "specificity" is just the recall (i.e. the sensitivity) on not having the disease, and less useful as a number that we actually care about.
This is because for rare events, low specificity implies low precision, but low precision does not necessarily result in low specificity.
Quite the opposite in fact, the rarer the event, the less you know about false positives with the medical terms.
But for some reason, the use of these different metrics established in the medical field...

My concerns are similar to yours about testing. Although, I think the paradox is really a question about where probabilities come from. I think that they stem from our own understanding (or beliefs), but most people I know think probabilities come from nature. If I’m right, then you will need to write every probability with given prior information. Accounting for prior information is the most important thing you can do in analyzing your data. Let me emphasize: what we really want to know is what conditions cause a type 1 or type 2 error.

Given what I wrote, it’s not very constructive using only two hypotheses in your model. It also makes very little sense saying the probability of an event without any context. A good doctor would tell you how certain he is about the results given what he knows about the person’s health and his medical knowledge and experience. The comment might be something like this: “Based on your history and the accuracy of the test, I believe that you are not sick. However, I’ve been surprised in the past, so there is a small possibility that you are actually sick. I recommend that you do <XYZ>.”

However, it is useful in considering an “ignorance prior” hypothesis in your model. What I am referring to is the scenario where the doctor knows absolutely nothing about medicine and the health of the patient and only knows what he sees in the test results. But this is fundamentally a Gaussian distribution given only two hypotheses.

PS Bayes Theorem is just the product rule. Let me know if you need to see a proof.

Some summary notes:

Sensitivity: how often the test is correct for those WITH the disease.
So, Sensitivity + FNR = 100%. The false NEGATIVE rate applies here because you're evaluating the samples that were ACTUALLY positive (i.e. WITH the disease), but TESTED negative.

Specificity: how often the test is correct for those WITHOUT the disease.
So, Specificity + FPR = 100%. The false POSITIVE rate applies here because you're evaluating the samples that were ACTUALLY negative (i.e. WITHOUT the disease), but TESTED positive.

This video illustrates why you have to keep in mind which evaluation metric you're using to evaluate your test. Accuracy is not a great metric for the reasons described at 3:48.
For something like breast cancer or Covid-19 virus detection, we actually don't care about the test's accuracy as much as we care about its Sensitivity: we want the test to have a high probability of detecting the ACTUAL positive cases for cancer/virus.

We don't necessarily care (as much) about the Specificity of the test. If we have a low Specificity, it just means the test will give more false alarms. Having a false alarm is (I think we'd all agree) much better than missing an Actual Positive.


This is also similar to why Accuracy is a misleading metric for situations when your data is heavily imbalanced. For example, say the airline industry wants a test to classify if a person is Terrorist vs Non-Terrorist. Well we know that the vast, vast, VAST majority of passengers are Non-Terrorist. Like 99.99% of passengers are not a terrorist. So if you had a simple "test" or "model" that simply classified each passenger as Non-Terrorist, that test would technically be very accurate: an accuracy of 99.99%. Sounds great right? Everyone agrees it's a great model with such high accuracy. WRONG! That test would naively miss Every. Single. Actual. Terrorist.

Evaluation metrics matter.

12:18: Algorithm for doing Bayes Rule:
Step 1: Convert your Prior Probability to Odds
Step 2: Calculate your Likelihood ("Bayes Factor") := Sensitivity / FPR
Step 3: Multiply

I often hear it said that humans are not good at handling probabilities in an intuitive way... but after seeing this, I feel like humans might be a little better at handling odds in an intuitive way, with a bit of exposure, experience, and guidance. Odds are, in essence, an extension of weighing two things against each other to compare their sizes/amounts, which is something that humans are pretty okay at - you can get a gut feeling about how much bigger a hundred jellybeans is, compared to five without having to count them all, sort of like we have an internal 'balance scale' that you can put things on either side of and get an intuitive idea about which is more and by what sort of magnitude. Probability asks you to weigh a part of a thing against the whole of the thing, which is probably where that balance scale in your brain becomes less useful, but you don't have different things on both sides, you have a big thing on one side, and part of that big thing on the other side, and it doesn't parse right. It might be better for the math in a lot of applications, but inside the head, the Odds are a little more graspable, being the comparing of two different things.

Being able to start with odds, and apply evidence as a factor to arrive at new odds, feels very intuitive as a way to understand how information updates confidence. The fact that it ends up being simple multiplication only makes it easier to get that kind of 'ballpark estimate', and this helps keep it in the realm of intuition without getting into the weeds. At that point it's just getting people used to how to pull a Bayes Factor for the odds they want to update out of the test info - and that's mostly a matter of context and communication. Without a bit of practice, it could be fairly easy to blindly apply the 'wrong factor'.

I'm an engineer who has worked on many systems in multiple safety-critical and life-critical industries, including radiation monitoring systems, reactor control systems, aircraft instrumentation, robotics for hazardous environments, and more. Not everything can be tested as well as we might wish, so the goal of experiments is to generate descriptive statistics from which we can reliably and confidently estimate the expected real-world performance.

I learned some solid engineering statistics as an undergrad in the 1980s, but soon after starting my first job I encountered the limitations of those classes and started studying the field called Design of Experiments (DoE), which boils down to ensuring whatever test process you design, from the setup to data acquisition and through analysis, is *able* to yield useful predictions.

While I felt very much empowered by this new knowledge and skillset, I also felt the nagging doubt that I could still be wrong, that I may only have learned "enough to get myself in trouble". So I went to the place where I thought DoE was truly the most life-critical: Medical studies. And I was shocked by the amount of statistical ignorance, slop and trash I found there. This was in the early 1990s, and I was looking at "important" studies from the prior 15 years.

Fortunately, the situation has vastly improved since then, at least in the medical community (I highly recommend reading everything John Cook blogs or tweets in this area). But now I'm seeing engineering graduates becoming more tool and theory oriented, and are not being given a solid grounding in engineering stats and DoE.

I can't count the times I've walked medical practitioners (mainly nurses) through the Basics of Bayes, because as I age I'm naturally seeing more positive test results, yet never want to undergo any unnecessary treatment. This video, after a couple re-watchings, is certain to make that task simpler, and hopefully more productive.

I would dearly love to see this treatment extended to DoE!

"Reductio ad absurdum"  Urine/serum pregnancy test has a sensitivity ~99% and specificity of ~99%, i.e. it works REALLY well in the lab.  However, if you test a population of males (prior near 0%), then ALL + results are FALSE POSITIVES.  Conversely, if you test a population of  young women, sexually active, who have "missed" a couple periods, then almost all + will be true +; whereas, almost all negatives will be false negatives.  The TEST is exactly the same, but the INTERPRETATION is entirely different based on the population/prior probability.   Your point that any given test only modifies the PRIOR PROBABILITY is a wonderful and highly intuitive way to approach this subject.

The formula with odds is beautiful but I think most already have a more intuitive approach for updating their belief:

You imagine:
* how many of positive tests should come from positive cases
* how many should come from negative cases
* the probability of it being from a positive case given the positive test is just the fraction of the former to the latter

Formally it can be expressed as odds but odds are unfortunately not what most of us often deal with.

e.g.
from positive cases: 1 % have disease * true positive rate
vs
from negative cases: 99 % do not have disease * false positive rate

which for these examples and easy calculation is roughly
1 %
vs
the false positive rate

in the first example, the specificity was 91 % so the FPR is 9 %. So simply, 1 % vs 9 %, so about 1/10. The rest as simple.

This general approach of just simulating the generative process that gave rise to the observations should come naturally and apply to most situations.

I also find it helpful to think about prevalence versus false positive rate. A disease with 1% prevalence and a test with a 10% false positive rate is 10x more likely to show a false positive than a true positive, simply because there are 10x fewer people with the disease (1% versus 10%), so the probability of actually having the disease is a little under 10% (1 in 11). If the prevalence and false positive rate are both 10%, then a positive test result is (roughly) equally likely to be a true positive or a false positive, since there are the same number of true & false positives in the population, so the probability of actually having the disease is about 50%

As doctors, we use this every day, often without thinking about the mathematical foundations.
Unfortunately, very few diagnostic tests ou exams are indeed both sensitive AND specific.
So, if we think a diagnostic unlikely (based on prevalence, physical exam, previous tests, ...), we choose first the more sensitive test in order to exclude this diagnostic.
On the contrary, if a diagnostic is very probable, we choose first a specific test to confirm.
It is not always easy for technical exams, as we can often only choose between them (if there are several !), without changing their sensitivity and specificity. But for biological tests, we can adjust our cutting values to improve either sensitivity or specificity.

Educators need to design ways that don't feel mathematical of using what amounts to Bayes Theorem by 3rd Grade (8 years old in the US) or so. They already do some. For instance, all the students over 5' tall in a class are girls. Does that mean all the girls' are over 5' tall? That's a start. But it needs to be imprinted with numbers.

Say 3 of the students are over 5' tall, and they're all girls. There are 12 boys and 12 girls in the class. If the next person to read is a girl, is it more likely that the next reader she's over 5' tall or that they're not? (Almost everyone gets the right answer.) Then ask why not, even though all the 5' tall people are girls. Let them explain it to each other.

Even without probability notation (which, frankly, stinks) by the time they're in 8th Grade, most of them should have a solid intuitive understanding of Bayes Theorem and its implications. There are few skills that are as important in making sense of the world around us yet so underemphasized in school math.

It seems odds are way easier to understand when it comes to making individual decisions or determinations. Probability is useful when you are examining the effects on a population or computing expected values. From the medical/pharmaceutical industry's perspective, they look at populations more than individuals, so it makes sense that they use probabilities to express the effectiveness of their treatments, but a patient or a consumer (and doctors to a certain extent) is not concerned about the population they are a part of. They want to know whether they've got a disease or not. It's just their individual case, so odds can be more helpful in conveying less confusable information.

The representation as odds is nothing short genius -- but one way it might be improved is by framing the Bayes factor as odds itself -- If we represent it as the Sensitivity to the False positive rate : S:FPR then the odds update even more naturally in my option:

here we have 90:9 (simplified to 10:1) sensitivity to false positives, which we can straightforwardly multiply with any odds like 1:99 in the exact same way just treating the left and right as seperate (10:99).

This also gives an intuitive explanation for the exact "updating" the Bayes factor is doing -- we are multiplying the odds you have the disease by the probabilty of a positive test result given you have the dosease (sensitivity), and the odds you don't have the disease by the probability of a positive test result given you don't have the disease (false positive rate). I think naming this factor something like the intensifying factor of the test, as a lay alternative to Bayes factor, as it "intensifies" the odds on either side.

You don't have to know any Bayesian logic in order to solve the question for doctors about breast cancer. You just need to know 6th grade mathematics.
Let x be the number of women with positive result on the test for camcer
Let y be the number of women with negative result on the test for cancer.
Since 1% of women in that age have cancer, we know that x/y = 1/ 100
therefore 100x = y
Since the are both 90% the number of women who actually have cancer can also be expressed as
90% x + 10% y = 0.9x + 0.1y
The probability that a woman which has a positive test also has cancer is 0.9x / (0.9x + 0.1y)
Replace y = 100x and you get
0.9x / (0.9x + 10x) = 0.9x / 10.9x which is roughly around 1/11 which is a little bit less then 10%.

Once again, these kind of problems more likely lend themselves to a language or interpretation issue. To laypeople, 'Accuracy' can mean a variety of things.

Additionally, Accuracy is typically the only number presented/talked about and it hides the Sensitivity and Specificity. And further still the Prevalence (or Prior) still needs mentioned to give the full picture of the true odds.

(Also, I love the note you make about not reporting Bayes Factor in terms of a %. Percents can be very misleading when given without extra context about the sample. Super helpful in explaining intuition.)

5:16 Here's how I like to define a fallacy and a paradox:

Suppose you have a good argument leading to an absurd statement. If you can find a flaw in the argument, then you have a fallacy. On the other hand, if you find that the statement is true after all, then you have a paradox.

According to this definition, it IS a paradox. The argument is actually good, and the statement is also true, it's just counterintuitive.

If you want good information on how to use Bayes Theorem for determining whether a hypothesis is likely to be true, you should read, "Proving History", by Richard Carrier. He then applies Bayes Theorem to a historical hypothesis in its sequel, "On The Historicity Of Jesus". I highly recommend these books, and they're also available as audiobooks on Audible, so that's a plus. Carrier is a Ph.D. historian, and the works are peer-reviewed, but are very readable, and give all the details a layperson would need to apply Bayes Theorem themself. Interestingly, Carrier relies on the odds form in his books, which @3blue1brown relies on in this video.
